flashcards.definition: The philosophical study of what makes a person the same over time despite changes.
The condition of being one and the same entity through time.
The metaphysical study of existence, focusing on what it means to be a person.
Include body-based, soul-based, and psychological continuity theories.
The idea that personal identity is tied to having the same physical body over time.
The belief that a person remains the same if they possess the same soul over time.
Defines personal identity in terms of continuity of memory and consciousness.

flashcards.term: Brian Smart’s Ship Identity Thought Experiment
flashcards.definition: A case exploring whether identity is retained when an object’s parts are replaced.

flashcards.term: John Perry’s Brain Swap Thought Experiment
flashcards.definition: A scenario questioning if personal identity follows the brain or the body.
Argues that identity is not as important as psychological continuity and survival.
Explores the problem of identity when one brain is divided into two separate bodies.
Views identity as the Atman, an unchanging true self distinct from the material world.
The eternal, unchanging self in Hindu philosophy.
The ultimate reality in Hinduism, with which Atman is identical.
The law of cosmic justice that affects one's future existence based on actions.
Liberation from the cycle of birth and rebirth in Hinduism.
The illusionary nature of the material world, according to Hindu philosophy.
Rejects the idea of a permanent self, arguing that identity is an illusion.
The Buddhist doctrine that denies a permanent, unchanging self.
The five components—form, sensation, perception, mental formations, and consciousness—that make up a person.
The cycle of birth, death, and rebirth in Hinduism and Buddhism.
Buddhist teachings that state all things are impermanent (anicca), lead to suffering (dukkha), and lack a permanent self (anatta).
The Buddhist state of liberation, free from suffering and self-illusion.
Argued that there is no consistent self, only a bundle of perceptions.
Famously stated that one cannot step into the same river twice, highlighting the idea that identity is constantly changing.
A scenario that questions whether a person transported atom by atom remains the same person.
The idea of an inner self-nature that makes a person unique.
The Buddhist concept that all things arise in dependence on other factors, reinforcing the rejection of a permanent self.

flashcards.term: Comparing Hinduism & Buddhism on the Self
flashcards.definition: Hinduism believes in an eternal Atman, while Buddhism rejects the idea of a permanent self.
Hinduism views identity as continuous through reincarnation, while Buddhism sees rebirth as a process without a permanent self.
The belief that everything is ultimately Brahman and individuality is an illusion.
Cases like the Ship of Theseus illustrate how identity can be debated in practical contexts.
Defines personal identity in terms of continuity of psychological traits and memories.

flashcards.term: Parfit’s View on the Unimportance of Identity
flashcards.definition: Suggests that what matters is psychological continuity rather than a fixed identity.

flashcards.term: The Problem of Personal Identity in Modern Science
flashcards.definition: Advances in neuroscience challenge traditional views on the self by showing how identity is shaped by brain function.
